channel.title: TEDTalks (audio)
channel.description: TED is a nonprofit devoted to Ideas Worth Spreading. On this feed, you'll find TEDTalks video to inspire, intrigue and stir the imagination from some of the world's leading thinkers and doers, speaking from the stage at TED conferences, TEDx events and partner events around the world. This podcast is also available in high-def video and audio-only formats.
channel.itunes:subtitle: TED is a nonprofit devoted to Ideas Worth Spreading. On this feed, you'll find TEDTalks video to inspire, intrigue and stir the imagination from some of the world's leading thinkers and doers, speaking from the stage at TED conferences, TEDx events and pa
channel.itunes:author: TEDTalks
channel.itunes:summary: TED is a nonprofit devoted to Ideas Worth Spreading. On this feed, you'll find TEDTalks video to inspire, intrigue and stir the imagination from some of the world's leading thinkers and doers, speaking from the stage at TED conferences, TEDx events and partner events around the world. This podcast is also available in high-def video and audio-only formats.
channel.itunes:keywords: TED, TEDTalks, TED Talks, inspiration, creativity, tech demo, education
channel.media:keywords: TED, TEDTalks, TED Talks, inspiration, creativity, tech demo, education
channel.feedburner:browserFriendly: Each year, the TED Conference hosts some of the world's most fascinating people: Trusted voices and convention-breaking mavericks, icons and geniuses. These podcasts (available also in video) capture the most extraordinary presentations delivered from the TED stage. Each week, we'll release a new talk to inspire, intrigue and stir the imagination. For best effect, plan to listen to at least three, start to finish. (They have a cumulative effect.) If you have a curious soul and an open mind, we think you'll be hooked...

item.title: TED: Daniel Pauly: The ocean's shifting baseline - Daniel Pauly (2010)
item.itunes:author: Daniel Pauly
item.description: The ocean has degraded within our lifetimes, as shown in the decreasing average size of fish. And yet, as Daniel Pauly shows us onstage at Mission Blue, each time the baseline drops, we call it the new "normal." At what point do we stop readjusting downward?
item.itunes:subtitle: Daniel Pauly: The ocean's shifting baseline
item.itunes:summary: The ocean has degraded within our lifetimes, as shown in the decreasing average size of fish. And yet, as Daniel Pauly shows us onstage at Mission Blue, each time the baseline drops, we call it the new "normal." At what point do we stop readjusting downward?
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Lucien Engelen: Crowdsource your health - Lucien Engelen (2011)
item.itunes:author: Lucien Engelen
item.description: You can use your smartphone to find a local ATM, but what if you need a defibrillator? At TEDxMaastricht, Lucien Engelen shows us online innovations that are changing the way we save lives, including a crowdsourced map of local defibrillators.
item.itunes:subtitle: Lucien Engelen: Crowdsource your health
item.itunes:summary: You can use your smartphone to find a local ATM, but what if you need a defibrillator? At TEDxMaastricht, Lucien Engelen shows us online innovations that are changing the way we save lives, including a crowdsourced map of local defibrillators.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Inara George sings 'Family Tree' - Inara George (2010)
item.itunes:author: Inara George
item.description: Singer Inara George and guitarist Mike Andrews play the quietly lovely love song "Family Tree."
item.itunes:subtitle: Inara George sings 'Family Tree'
item.itunes:summary: Singer Inara George and guitarist Mike Andrews play the quietly lovely love song "Family Tree."
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Mike deGruy: Hooked by an octopus - Mike deGruy (2010)
item.itunes:author: Mike deGruy
item.description: Underwater filmmaker Mike deGruy has spent decades looking intimately at the ocean. A consummate storyteller, he takes the stage at Mission Blue to share his awe and excitement -- and his fears -- about the blue heart of our planet.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mike deGruy: Hooked by an octopus
item.itunes:summary: Underwater filmmaker Mike deGruy has spent decades looking intimately at the ocean. A consummate storyteller, he takes the stage at Mission Blue to share his awe and excitement -- and his fears -- about the blue heart of our planet.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Danny Hillis: Back to the future (of 1994) - Danny Hillis (1994)
item.itunes:author: Danny Hillis
item.description: From deep in the TED archive, Danny Hillis outlines an intriguing theory of how and why technological change seems to be accelerating, by linking it to the very evolution of life itself. The presentation techniques he uses may look dated, but the ideas are as relevant as ever.
item.itunes:subtitle: Danny Hillis: Back to the future (of 1994)
item.itunes:summary: From deep in the TED archive, Danny Hillis outlines an intriguing theory of how and why technological change seems to be accelerating, by linking it to the very evolution of life itself. The presentation techniques he uses may look dated, but the ideas are as relevant as ever.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Erica Frenkel: The universal anesthesia machine - Erica Frenkel (2011)
item.itunes:author: Erica Frenkel
item.description: What if you're in surgery and the power goes out? No lights, no oxygen -- and your anesthesia stops flowing. It happens constantly in hospitals throughout the world, turning routine procedures into tragedies. Erica Frenkel demos one solution: the universal anesthesia machine.
item.itunes:subtitle: Erica Frenkel: The universal anesthesia machine
item.itunes:summary: What if you're in surgery and the power goes out? No lights, no oxygen -- and your anesthesia stops flowing. It happens constantly in hospitals throughout the world, turning routine procedures into tragedies. Erica Frenkel demos one solution: the universal anesthesia machine.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Lisa Harouni: A primer on 3D printing - Lisa Harouni (2011)
item.itunes:author: Lisa Harouni
item.description: 2012 may be the year of 3D printing, when this three-decade-old technology finally becomes accessible and even commonplace. Lisa Harouni gives a useful introduction to this fascinating way of making things -- including intricate objects once impossible to create.
item.itunes:subtitle: Lisa Harouni: A primer on 3D printing
item.itunes:summary: 2012 may be the year of 3D printing, when this three-decade-old technology finally becomes accessible and even commonplace. Lisa Harouni gives a useful introduction to this fascinating way of making things -- including intricate objects once impossible to create.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Alain de Botton: Atheism 2.0 - Alain de Botton (2011)
item.itunes:author: Alain de Botton
item.description: What aspects of religion should atheists (respectfully) adopt? Alain de Botton suggests a "religion for atheists" -- call it Atheism 2.0 -- that incorporates religious forms and traditions to satisfy our human need for connection, ritual and transcendence.
item.itunes:subtitle: Alain de Botton: Atheism 2.0
item.itunes:summary: What aspects of religion should atheists (respectfully) adopt? Alain de Botton suggests a "religion for atheists" -- call it Atheism 2.0 -- that incorporates religious forms and traditions to satisfy our human need for connection, ritual and transcendence.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Sonaar Luthra: Meet the Water Canary - Sonaar Luthra (2011)
item.itunes:author: Sonaar Luthra
item.description: After a crisis, how can we tell if water is safe to drink? Current tests are slow and complex, and the delay can be deadly, as in the cholera outbreak after Haiti's earthquake in 2010. TED Fellow Sonaar Luthra previews his design for a simple tool that quickly tests water for safety -- the Water Canary.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sonaar Luthra: Meet the Water Canary
item.itunes:summary: After a crisis, how can we tell if water is safe to drink? Current tests are slow and complex, and the delay can be deadly, as in the cholera outbreak after Haiti's earthquake in 2010. TED Fellow Sonaar Luthra previews his design for a simple tool that quickly tests water for safety -- the Water Canary.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Sebastian Wernicke: 1000 TEDTalks, 6 words - Sebastian Wernicke (2011)
item.itunes:author: Sebastian Wernicke
item.description: Sebastian Wernicke thinks every TEDTalk can be summarized in six words. At TEDxZurich, he shows how to do just that -- and less.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sebastian Wernicke: 1000 TEDTalks, 6 words
item.itunes:summary: Sebastian Wernicke thinks every TEDTalk can be summarized in six words. At TEDxZurich, he shows how to do just that -- and less.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Jane Fonda: Life's third act - Jane Fonda (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jane Fonda
item.description: Within this generation, an extra 30 years have been added to our life expectancy -- and these years aren’t just a footnote or a pathology. At TEDxWomen, Jane Fonda asks how we can think about this new phase of our lives.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jane Fonda: Life's third act
item.itunes:summary: Within this generation, an extra 30 years have been added to our life expectancy -- and these years aren’t just a footnote or a pathology. At TEDxWomen, Jane Fonda asks how we can think about this new phase of our lives.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: A.J. Jacobs: How healthy living nearly killed me - A.J. Jacobs (2011)
item.itunes:author: A.J. Jacobs
item.description: For a full year, A.J. Jacobs followed every piece of health advice he could -- from applying sunscreen by the shot glass to wearing a bicycle helmet while shopping. Onstage at TEDMED, he shares the surprising things he learned.
item.itunes:subtitle: A.J. Jacobs: How healthy living nearly killed me
item.itunes:summary: For a full year, A.J. Jacobs followed every piece of health advice he could -- from applying sunscreen by the shot glass to wearing a bicycle helmet while shopping. Onstage at TEDMED, he shares the surprising things he learned.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Karen Tse: How to stop torture - Karen Tse (2011)
item.itunes:author: Karen Tse
item.description: Political prisoners aren't the only ones being tortured -- the vast majority of judicial torture happens in ordinary cases, even in 'functioning' legal systems. Social activist Karen Tse shows how we can, and should, stand up and end the use of routine torture.
item.itunes:subtitle: Karen Tse: How to stop torture
item.itunes:summary: Political prisoners aren't the only ones being tortured -- the vast majority of judicial torture happens in ordinary cases, even in 'functioning' legal systems. Social activist Karen Tse shows how we can, and should, stand up and end the use of routine torture.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Daniel Goldstein: The battle between your present and future self - Daniel Goldstein (2011)
item.itunes:author: Daniel Goldstein
item.description: Every day, we make decisions that have good or bad consequences for our future selves. (Can I skip flossing just this one time?) Daniel Goldstein makes tools that help us imagine ourselves over time, so that we make smart choices for Future Us.
item.itunes:subtitle: Daniel Goldstein: The battle between your present and future self
item.itunes:summary: Every day, we make decisions that have good or bad consequences for our future selves. (Can I skip flossing just this one time?) Daniel Goldstein makes tools that help us imagine ourselves over time, so that we make smart choices for Future Us.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Sheila Nirenberg: A prosthetic eye to treat blindness - Sheila Nirenberg (2011)
item.itunes:author: Sheila Nirenberg
item.description: At TEDMED, Sheila Nirenberg shows a bold way to create sight in people with certain kinds of blindness: by hooking into the optic nerve and sending signals from a camera direct to the brain.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sheila Nirenberg: A prosthetic eye to treat blindness
item.itunes:summary: At TEDMED, Sheila Nirenberg shows a bold way to create sight in people with certain kinds of blindness: by hooking into the optic nerve and sending signals from a camera direct to the brain.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Antonio Damasio: The quest to understand consciousness - Antonio Damasio (2011)
item.itunes:author: Antonio Damasio
item.description: Every morning we wake up and regain consciousness -- that is a marvelous fact -- but what exactly is it that we regain? Neuroscientist Antonio Damasio uses this simple question to give us a glimpse into how our brains create our sense of self.
item.itunes:subtitle: Antonio Damasio: The quest to understand consciousness
item.itunes:summary: Every morning we wake up and regain consciousness -- that is a marvelous fact -- but what exactly is it that we regain? Neuroscientist Antonio Damasio uses this simple question to give us a glimpse into how our brains create our sense of self.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Ramona Pierson: An unexpected place of healing - Ramona Pierson (2011)
item.itunes:author: Ramona Pierson
item.description: When Ramona Pierson was 22, she was hit by a drunk driver and spent 18 months in a coma. At TEDxDU she tells the remarkable story of her recovery -- drawing on the collective skills and wisdom of a senior citizens' home.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ramona Pierson: An unexpected place of healing
item.itunes:summary: When Ramona Pierson was 22, she was hit by a drunk driver and spent 18 months in a coma. At TEDxDU she tells the remarkable story of her recovery -- drawing on the collective skills and wisdom of a senior citizens' home.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Homaro Cantu + Ben Roche: Cooking as alchemy - Homaro Cantu / Ben Roche (2011)
item.itunes:author: Homaro Cantu / Ben Roche
item.description: Homaro Cantu and Ben Roche come from Moto, a Chicago restaurant that plays with new ways to cook and eat food. But beyond the fun and flavor-tripping, there's a serious intent: Can we use new food technology for good?
item.itunes:subtitle: Homaro Cantu + Ben Roche: Cooking as alchemy
item.itunes:summary: Homaro Cantu and Ben Roche come from Moto, a Chicago restaurant that plays with new ways to cook and eat food. But beyond the fun and flavor-tripping, there's a serious intent: Can we use new food technology for good?
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Pavan Sukhdev: Put a value on nature! - Pavan Sukhdev (2011)
item.itunes:author: Pavan Sukhdev
item.description: Every day, we use materials from the earth without thinking, for free. But what if we had to pay for their true value: would it make us more careful about what we use and what we waste? Think of Pavan Sukhdev as nature's banker -- assessing the value of the Earth's assets. Eye-opening charts will make you think differently about the cost of air, water, trees ...
item.itunes:subtitle: Pavan Sukhdev: Put a value on nature!
item.itunes:summary: Every day, we use materials from the earth without thinking, for free. But what if we had to pay for their true value: would it make us more careful about what we use and what we waste? Think of Pavan Sukhdev as nature's banker -- assessing the value of the Earth's assets. Eye-opening charts will make you think differently about the cost of air, water, trees ...
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Quyen Nguyen: Color-coded surgery - Quyen Nguyen (2011)
item.itunes:author: Quyen Nguyen
item.description: Surgeons are taught from textbooks which conveniently color-code the types of tissues, but that's not what it looks like in real life -- until now. At TEDMED Quyen Nguyen demonstrates how a molecular marker can make tumors light up in neon green, showing surgeons exactly where to cut.
item.itunes:subtitle: Quyen Nguyen: Color-coded surgery
item.itunes:summary: Surgeons are taught from textbooks which conveniently color-code the types of tissues, but that's not what it looks like in real life -- until now. At TEDMED Quyen Nguyen demonstrates how a molecular marker can make tumors light up in neon green, showing surgeons exactly where to cut.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Monika Bulaj: The hidden light of Afghanistan - Monika Bulaj (2011)
item.itunes:author: Monika Bulaj
item.description: Photographer Monika Bulaj shares powerful, intimate images of Afghanistan -- of home life, of ritual, of men and women. Behind the headlines, what does the world truly know about this place?
item.itunes:subtitle: Monika Bulaj: The hidden light of Afghanistan
item.itunes:summary: Photographer Monika Bulaj shares powerful, intimate images of Afghanistan -- of home life, of ritual, of men and women. Behind the headlines, what does the world truly know about this place?
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Stefon Harris: There are no mistakes on the bandstand - Stefon Harris (2011)
item.itunes:author: Stefon Harris
item.description: What is a mistake? By talking through examples with his improvisational Jazz quartet, Stefon Harris walks us to a profound truth: many actions are perceived as mistakes only because we don't react to them appropriately.
item.itunes:subtitle: Stefon Harris: There are no mistakes on the bandstand
item.itunes:summary: What is a mistake? By talking through examples with his improvisational Jazz quartet, Stefon Harris walks us to a profound truth: many actions are perceived as mistakes only because we don't react to them appropriately.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Cheryl Hayashi: The magnificence of spider silk - Cheryl Hayashi (2010)
item.itunes:author: Cheryl Hayashi
item.description: Cheryl Hayashi studies spider silk, one of nature's most high-performance materials. Each species of spider can make up to 7 very different kinds of silk. How do they do it? Hayashi explains at the DNA level -- then shows us how this super-strong, super-flexible material can inspire.
item.itunes:subtitle: Cheryl Hayashi: The magnificence of spider silk
item.itunes:summary: Cheryl Hayashi studies spider silk, one of nature's most high-performance materials. Each species of spider can make up to 7 very different kinds of silk. How do they do it? Hayashi explains at the DNA level -- then shows us how this super-strong, super-flexible material can inspire.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Kathryn Schulz: Don't regret regret - Kathryn Schulz (2011)
item.itunes:author: Kathryn Schulz
item.description: We're taught to try to live life without regret. But why? Using her own tattoo as an example, Kathryn Schulz makes a powerful and moving case for embracing our regrets.
item.itunes:subtitle: Kathryn Schulz: Don't regret regret
item.itunes:summary: We're taught to try to live life without regret. But why? Using her own tattoo as an example, Kathryn Schulz makes a powerful and moving case for embracing our regrets.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Charles Limb: Building the musical muscle - Charles Limb (2011)
item.itunes:author: Charles Limb
item.description: Charles Limb performs cochlear implantation, a surgery that treats hearing loss and can restore the ability to hear speech. But as a musician too, Limb thinks about what the implants lack: They don't let you fully experience music yet. (There's a hair-raising example.) At TEDMED, Limb reviews the state of the art and the way forward.
item.itunes:subtitle: Charles Limb: Building the musical muscle
item.itunes:summary: Charles Limb performs cochlear implantation, a surgery that treats hearing loss and can restore the ability to hear speech. But as a musician too, Limb thinks about what the implants lack: They don't let you fully experience music yet. (There's a hair-raising example.) At TEDMED, Limb reviews the state of the art and the way forward.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Annie Murphy Paul: What we learn before we're born - Annie Murphy Paul (2011)
item.itunes:author: Annie Murphy Paul
item.description: Pop quiz: When does learning begin? Answer: Before we are born. Science writer Annie Murphy Paul talks through new research that shows how much we learn in the womb -- from the lilt of our native language to our soon-to-be-favorite foods.
item.itunes:subtitle: Annie Murphy Paul: What we learn before we're born
item.itunes:summary: Pop quiz: When does learning begin? Answer: Before we are born. Science writer Annie Murphy Paul talks through new research that shows how much we learn in the womb -- from the lilt of our native language to our soon-to-be-favorite foods.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Damon Horowitz: Philosophy in prison - Damon Horowitz (2011)
item.itunes:author: Damon Horowitz
item.description: Damon Horowitz teaches philosophy through the Prison University Project, bringing college-level classes to inmates of San Quentin State Prison. In this powerful short talk, he tells the story of an encounter with right and wrong that quickly gets personal.
item.itunes:subtitle: Damon Horowitz: Philosophy in prison
item.itunes:summary: Damon Horowitz teaches philosophy through the Prison University Project, bringing college-level classes to inmates of San Quentin State Prison. In this powerful short talk, he tells the story of an encounter with right and wrong that quickly gets personal.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Britta Riley: A garden in my apartment - Britta Riley (2011)
item.itunes:author: Britta Riley
item.description: Britta Riley wanted to grow her own food (in her tiny apartment). So she and her friends developed a system for growing plants in discarded plastic bottles -- researching, testing and tweaking the system using social media, trying many variations at once and quickly arriving at the optimal system. Call it distributed DIY. And the results? Delicious.
item.itunes:subtitle: Britta Riley: A garden in my apartment
item.itunes:summary: Britta Riley wanted to grow her own food (in her tiny apartment). So she and her friends developed a system for growing plants in discarded plastic bottles -- researching, testing and tweaking the system using social media, trying many variations at once and quickly arriving at the optimal system. Call it distributed DIY. And the results? Delicious.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Joe Sabia: The technology of storytelling - Joe Sabia (2011)
item.itunes:author: Joe Sabia
item.description: iPad storyteller Joe Sabia introduces us to Lothar Meggendorfer, who created a bold technology for storytelling: the pop-up book. Sabia shows how new technology has always helped us tell our own stories, from the walls of caves to his own onstage iPad.
item.itunes:subtitle: Joe Sabia: The technology of storytelling
item.itunes:summary: iPad storyteller Joe Sabia introduces us to Lothar Meggendorfer, who created a bold technology for storytelling: the pop-up book. Sabia shows how new technology has always helped us tell our own stories, from the walls of caves to his own onstage iPad.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Péter Fankhauser: Meet Rezero, the dancing ballbot - Péter Fankhauser (2011)
item.itunes:author: Péter Fankhauser
item.description: Onstage at TEDGlobal, Péter Fankhauser demonstrates Rezero, a robot that balances on a ball. Designed and built by a group of engineering students, Rezero is the first ballbot made to move quickly and gracefully -- and even dance.
item.itunes:subtitle: Péter Fankhauser: Meet Rezero, the dancing ballbot
item.itunes:summary: Onstage at TEDGlobal, Péter Fankhauser demonstrates Rezero, a robot that balances on a ball. Designed and built by a group of engineering students, Rezero is the first ballbot made to move quickly and gracefully -- and even dance.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Phil Plait: How to defend Earth from asteroids - Phil Plait (2011)
item.itunes:author: Phil Plait
item.description: What's six miles wide and can end civilization in an instant? An asteroid -- and there are lots of them out there. With humor and great visuals, Phil Plait enthralls the TEDxBoulder audience with all the ways asteroids can kill, and what we must do to avoid them.
item.itunes:subtitle: Phil Plait: How to defend Earth from asteroids
item.itunes:summary: What's six miles wide and can end civilization in an instant? An asteroid -- and there are lots of them out there. With humor and great visuals, Phil Plait enthralls the TEDxBoulder audience with all the ways asteroids can kill, and what we must do to avoid them.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Robin Ince: Science versus wonder? - Robin Ince (2011)
item.itunes:author: Robin Ince
item.description: Does science ruin the magic of life? In this grumpy but charming monologue, Robin Ince makes the argument against. The more we learn about the astonishing behavior of the universe -- the more we stand in awe.
item.itunes:subtitle: Robin Ince: Science versus wonder?
item.itunes:summary: Does science ruin the magic of life? In this grumpy but charming monologue, Robin Ince makes the argument against. The more we learn about the astonishing behavior of the universe -- the more we stand in awe.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Cynthia Kenyon: Experiments that hint of longer lives - Cynthia Kenyon (2011)
item.itunes:author: Cynthia Kenyon
item.description: What controls aging? Biochemist Cynthia Kenyon has found a simple genetic mutation that can double the lifespan of a simple worm, C. elegans. The lessons from that discovery, and others, are pointing to how we might one day significantly extend youthful human life.
item.itunes:subtitle: Cynthia Kenyon: Experiments that hint of longer lives
item.itunes:summary: What controls aging? Biochemist Cynthia Kenyon has found a simple genetic mutation that can double the lifespan of a simple worm, C. elegans. The lessons from that discovery, and others, are pointing to how we might one day significantly extend youthful human life.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Yves Rossy: Fly with the Jetman - Yves Rossy (2011)
item.itunes:author: Yves Rossy
item.description: Strapped to a jet-powered wing, Yves Rossy is the Jetman -- flying free, his body as the rudder, above the Swiss Alps and the Grand Canyon. After a powerful short film shows how it works, Rossy takes the TEDGlobal stage to share the experience and thrill of flying.
item.itunes:subtitle: Yves Rossy: Fly with the Jetman
item.itunes:summary: Strapped to a jet-powered wing, Yves Rossy is the Jetman -- flying free, his body as the rudder, above the Swiss Alps and the Grand Canyon. After a powerful short film shows how it works, Rossy takes the TEDGlobal stage to share the experience and thrill of flying.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Alexander Tsiaras: Conception to birth -- visualized - Alexander Tsiaras (2010)
item.itunes:author: Alexander Tsiaras
item.description: Image-maker Alexander Tsiaras shares a powerful medical visualization, showing human development from conception to birth and beyond. (Some graphic images.)
item.itunes:subtitle: Alexander Tsiaras: Conception to birth -- visualized
item.itunes:summary: Image-maker Alexander Tsiaras shares a powerful medical visualization, showing human development from conception to birth and beyond. (Some graphic images.)
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Charlie Todd: The shared experience of absurdity - Charlie Todd (2011)
item.itunes:author: Charlie Todd
item.description: Charlie Todd causes bizarre, hilarious, and unexpected public scenes: Seventy synchronized dancers in storefront windows, "ghostbusters" running through the New York Public Library, and the annual no-pants subway ride. At TEDxBloomington he shows how his group, Improv Everywhere, uses these scenes to bring people together.
item.itunes:subtitle: Charlie Todd: The shared experience of absurdity
item.itunes:summary: Charlie Todd causes bizarre, hilarious, and unexpected public scenes: Seventy synchronized dancers in storefront windows, "ghostbusters" running through the New York Public Library, and the annual no-pants subway ride. At TEDxBloomington he shows how his group, Improv Everywhere, uses these scenes to bring people together.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Allan Jones: A map of the brain - Allan Jones (2011)
item.itunes:author: Allan Jones
item.description: How can we begin to understand the way the brain works? The same way we begin to understand a city: by making a map. In this visually stunning talk, Allan Jones shows how his team is mapping which genes are turned on in each tiny region, and how it all connects up.
item.itunes:subtitle: Allan Jones: A map of the brain
item.itunes:summary: How can we begin to understand the way the brain works? The same way we begin to understand a city: by making a map. In this visually stunning talk, Allan Jones shows how his team is mapping which genes are turned on in each tiny region, and how it all connects up.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Ben Kacyra: Ancient wonders captured in 3D - Ben Kacyra (2011)
item.itunes:author: Ben Kacyra
item.description: Ancient monuments give us clues to astonishing past civilizations -- but they're under threat from pollution, war, neglect. Ben Kacyra, who invented a groundbreaking 3D scanning system, is using his invention to scan and preserve the world's heritage in archival detail. (Watch to the end for a little demo.)
item.itunes:subtitle: Ben Kacyra: Ancient wonders captured in 3D
item.itunes:summary: Ancient monuments give us clues to astonishing past civilizations -- but they're under threat from pollution, war, neglect. Ben Kacyra, who invented a groundbreaking 3D scanning system, is using his invention to scan and preserve the world's heritage in archival detail. (Watch to the end for a little demo.)
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Aparna Rao: High-tech art (with a sense of humor) - Aparna Rao (2012)
item.itunes:author: Aparna Rao
item.description: Artist and TED Fellow Aparna Rao re-imagines the familiar in surprising, often humorous ways. With her collaborator Soren Pors, Rao creates high-tech art installations -- a typewriter that sends emails, a camera that tracks you through the room only to make you invisible on screen -- that put a playful spin on ordinary objects and interactions.
item.itunes:subtitle: Aparna Rao: High-tech art (with a sense of humor)
item.itunes:summary: Artist and TED Fellow Aparna Rao re-imagines the familiar in surprising, often humorous ways. With her collaborator Soren Pors, Rao creates high-tech art installations -- a typewriter that sends emails, a camera that tracks you through the room only to make you invisible on screen -- that put a playful spin on ordinary objects and interactions.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Martin Hanczyc: The line between life and not-life - Martin Hanczyc (2011)
item.itunes:author: Martin Hanczyc
item.description: In his lab, Martin Hanczyc makes "protocells," experimental blobs of chemicals that behave like living cells. His work demonstrates how life might have first occurred on Earth ... and perhaps elsewhere too.
item.itunes:subtitle: Martin Hanczyc: The line between life and not-life
item.itunes:summary: In his lab, Martin Hanczyc makes "protocells," experimental blobs of chemicals that behave like living cells. His work demonstrates how life might have first occurred on Earth ... and perhaps elsewhere too.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Marco Tempest: Augmented reality, techno-magic - Marco Tempest (2011)
item.itunes:author: Marco Tempest
item.description: Using sleight-of-hand techniques and charming storytelling, illusionist Marco Tempest brings a jaunty stick figure to life onstage at TEDGlobal.
item.itunes:subtitle: Marco Tempest: Augmented reality, techno-magic
item.itunes:summary: Using sleight-of-hand techniques and charming storytelling, illusionist Marco Tempest brings a jaunty stick figure to life onstage at TEDGlobal.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Daniel Wolpert: The real reason for brains - Daniel Wolpert (2011)
item.itunes:author: Daniel Wolpert
item.description: Neuroscientist Daniel Wolpert starts from a surprising premise: the brain evolved, not to think or feel, but to control movement. In this entertaining, data-rich talk he gives us a glimpse into how the brain creates the grace and agility of human motion.
item.itunes:subtitle: Daniel Wolpert: The real reason for brains
item.itunes:summary: Neuroscientist Daniel Wolpert starts from a surprising premise: the brain evolved, not to think or feel, but to control movement. In this entertaining, data-rich talk he gives us a glimpse into how the brain creates the grace and agility of human motion.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Anna Mracek Dietrich: A plane you can drive - Anna Mracek Dietrich (2011)
item.itunes:author: Anna Mracek Dietrich
item.description: A flying car -- it's an iconic image of the future. But after 100 years of flight and automotive engineering, no one has really cracked the problem. Pilot Anna Mracek Dietrich and her team flipped the question, asking: Why not build a plane that you can drive?
item.itunes:subtitle: Anna Mracek Dietrich: A plane you can drive
item.itunes:summary: A flying car -- it's an iconic image of the future. But after 100 years of flight and automotive engineering, no one has really cracked the problem. Pilot Anna Mracek Dietrich and her team flipped the question, asking: Why not build a plane that you can drive?
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Paul Zak: Trust, morality -- and oxytocin - Paul Zak (2011)
item.itunes:author: Paul Zak
item.description: What drives our desire to behave morally? Neuroeconomist Paul Zak shows why he believes oxytocin (he calls it "the moral molecule") is responsible for trust, empathy and other feelings that help build a stable society.
item.itunes:subtitle: Paul Zak: Trust, morality -- and oxytocin
item.itunes:summary: What drives our desire to behave morally? Neuroeconomist Paul Zak shows why he believes oxytocin (he calls it "the moral molecule") is responsible for trust, empathy and other feelings that help build a stable society.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Hasan Elahi: FBI, here I am! - Hasan Elahi (2011)
item.itunes:author: Hasan Elahi
item.description: After he ended up on a watch list by accident, Hasan Elahi was advised by his local FBI agents to let them know when he was traveling. He did that and more ... much more.
item.itunes:subtitle: Hasan Elahi: FBI, here I am!
item.itunes:summary: After he ended up on a watch list by accident, Hasan Elahi was advised by his local FBI agents to let them know when he was traveling. He did that and more ... much more.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Béatrice Coron: Stories cut from paper - Béatrice Coron (2011)
item.itunes:author: Béatrice Coron
item.description: With scissors and paper, artist Béatrice Coron creates intricate worlds, cities and countries, heavens and hells. Striding onstage in a glorious cape cut from Tyvek, she describes her creative process and the way her stories develop from snips and slices.
item.itunes:subtitle: Béatrice Coron: Stories cut from paper
item.itunes:summary: With scissors and paper, artist Béatrice Coron creates intricate worlds, cities and countries, heavens and hells. Striding onstage in a glorious cape cut from Tyvek, she describes her creative process and the way her stories develop from snips and slices.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Jay Bradner: Open-source cancer research - Jay Bradner (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jay Bradner
item.description: How does cancer know it's cancer? At Jay Bradner's lab, they found a molecule that might hold the answer, JQ1 -- and instead of patenting JQ1, they published their findings and mailed samples to 40 other labs to work on. An inspiring look at the open-source future of medical research.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jay Bradner: Open-source cancer research
item.itunes:summary: How does cancer know it's cancer? At Jay Bradner's lab, they found a molecule that might hold the answer, JQ1 -- and instead of patenting JQ1, they published their findings and mailed samples to 40 other labs to work on. An inspiring look at the open-source future of medical research.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Malcolm Gladwell: The strange tale of the Norden bombsight - Malcolm Gladwell (2011)
item.itunes:author: Malcolm Gladwell
item.description: Master storyteller Malcolm Gladwell tells the tale of the Norden bombsight, a groundbreaking piece of World War II technology with a deeply unexpected result.
item.itunes:subtitle: Malcolm Gladwell: The strange tale of the Norden bombsight
item.itunes:summary: Master storyteller Malcolm Gladwell tells the tale of the Norden bombsight, a groundbreaking piece of World War II technology with a deeply unexpected result.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Richard Wilkinson: How economic inequality harms societies - Richard Wilkinson (2011)
item.itunes:author: Richard Wilkinson
item.description: We feel instinctively that societies with huge income gaps are somehow going wrong. Richard Wilkinson charts the hard data on economic inequality, and shows what gets worse when rich and poor are too far apart: real effects on health, lifespan, even such basic values as trust.
item.itunes:subtitle: Richard Wilkinson: How economic inequality harms societies
item.itunes:summary: We feel instinctively that societies with huge income gaps are somehow going wrong. Richard Wilkinson charts the hard data on economic inequality, and shows what gets worse when rich and poor are too far apart: real effects on health, lifespan, even such basic values as trust.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Nathalie Miebach: Art made of storms - Nathalie Miebach (2011)
item.itunes:author: Nathalie Miebach
item.description: Artist Nathalie Miebach takes weather data from massive storms and turns it into complex sculptures that embody the forces of nature and time. These sculptures then become musical scores for a string quartet to play.
item.itunes:subtitle: Nathalie Miebach: Art made of storms
item.itunes:summary: Artist Nathalie Miebach takes weather data from massive storms and turns it into complex sculptures that embody the forces of nature and time. These sculptures then become musical scores for a string quartet to play.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Todd Kuiken: A prosthetic arm that "feels" - Todd Kuiken (2011)
item.itunes:author: Todd Kuiken
item.description: Physiatrist and engineer Todd Kuiken is building a prosthetic arm that connects with the human nervous system -- improving motion, control and even feeling. Onstage, patient Amanda Kitts helps demonstrate this next-gen robotic arm.
item.itunes:subtitle: Todd Kuiken: A prosthetic arm that "feels"
item.itunes:summary: Physiatrist and engineer Todd Kuiken is building a prosthetic arm that connects with the human nervous system -- improving motion, control and even feeling. Onstage, patient Amanda Kitts helps demonstrate this next-gen robotic arm.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Justin Hall-Tipping: Freeing energy from the grid - Justin Hall-Tipping (2011)
item.itunes:author: Justin Hall-Tipping
item.description: What would happen if we could generate power from our windowpanes? In this moving talk, entrepreneur Justin Hall-Tipping shows the materials that could make that possible, and how questioning our notion of 'normal' can lead to extraordinary breakthroughs.
item.itunes:subtitle: Justin Hall-Tipping: Freeing energy from the grid
item.itunes:summary: What would happen if we could generate power from our windowpanes? In this moving talk, entrepreneur Justin Hall-Tipping shows the materials that could make that possible, and how questioning our notion of 'normal' can lead to extraordinary breakthroughs.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Jae Rhim Lee: My mushroom burial suit - Jae Rhim Lee (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jae Rhim Lee
item.description: Here's a powerful provocation from artist Jae Rhim Lee. Can we commit our bodies to a cleaner, greener Earth, even after death? Naturally -- using a special burial suit seeded with pollution-gobbling mushrooms. Yes, this just might be the strangest TEDTalk you'll ever see ...
item.itunes:subtitle: Jae Rhim Lee: My mushroom burial suit
item.itunes:summary: Here's a powerful provocation from artist Jae Rhim Lee. Can we commit our bodies to a cleaner, greener Earth, even after death? Naturally -- using a special burial suit seeded with pollution-gobbling mushrooms. Yes, this just might be the strangest TEDTalk you'll ever see ...
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Pamela Meyer: How to spot a liar - Pamela Meyer (2011)
item.itunes:author: Pamela Meyer
item.description: On any given day we're lied to from 10 to 200 times, and the clues to detect those lie can be subtle and counter-intuitive. Pamela Meyer, author of Liespotting, shows the manners and "hotspots" used by those trained to recognize deception -- and she argues honesty is a value worth preserving.
item.itunes:subtitle: Pamela Meyer: How to spot a liar
item.itunes:summary: On any given day we're lied to from 10 to 200 times, and the clues to detect those lie can be subtle and counter-intuitive. Pamela Meyer, author of Liespotting, shows the manners and "hotspots" used by those trained to recognize deception -- and she argues honesty is a value worth preserving.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Ian Ritchie: The day I turned down Tim Berners-Lee - Ian Ritchie (2011)
item.itunes:author: Ian Ritchie
item.description: Imagine it's late 1990, and you've just met a nice young man named Tim Berners-Lee, who starts telling you about his proposed system called the World Wide Web. Ian Ritchie was there. And ... he didn't buy it. A short story about information, connectivity and learning from mistakes.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ian Ritchie: The day I turned down Tim Berners-Lee
item.itunes:summary: Imagine it's late 1990, and you've just met a nice young man named Tim Berners-Lee, who starts telling you about his proposed system called the World Wide Web. Ian Ritchie was there. And ... he didn't buy it. A short story about information, connectivity and learning from mistakes.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Richard Seymour: How beauty feels - Richard Seymour (2011)
item.itunes:author: Richard Seymour
item.description: A story, a work of art, a face, a designed object -- how do we tell that something is beautiful? And why does it matter so much to us? Designer Richard Seymour explores our response to beauty and the surprising power of objects that exhibit it.
item.itunes:subtitle: Richard Seymour: How beauty feels
item.itunes:summary: A story, a work of art, a face, a designed object -- how do we tell that something is beautiful? And why does it matter so much to us? Designer Richard Seymour explores our response to beauty and the surprising power of objects that exhibit it.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Alison Gopnik: What do babies think? - Alison Gopnik (2011)
item.itunes:author: Alison Gopnik
item.description: "Babies and young children are like the R&D division of the human species," says psychologist Alison Gopnik. Her research explores the sophisticated intelligence-gathering and decision-making that babies are really doing when they play.
item.itunes:subtitle: Alison Gopnik: What do babies think?
item.itunes:summary: "Babies and young children are like the R&D division of the human species," says psychologist Alison Gopnik. Her research explores the sophisticated intelligence-gathering and decision-making that babies are really doing when they play.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Charles Hazlewood: Trusting the ensemble - Charles Hazlewood (2011)
item.itunes:author: Charles Hazlewood
item.description: Conductor Charles Hazlewood talks about the role of trust in musical leadership -- then shows how it works, as he conducts the Scottish Ensemble onstage. He also shares clips from two musical projects: the opera "U-Carmen eKhayelitsha" and the ParaOrchestra.
item.itunes:subtitle: Charles Hazlewood: Trusting the ensemble
item.itunes:summary: Conductor Charles Hazlewood talks about the role of trust in musical leadership -- then shows how it works, as he conducts the Scottish Ensemble onstage. He also shares clips from two musical projects: the opera "U-Carmen eKhayelitsha" and the ParaOrchestra.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Mike Biddle: We can recycle plastic - Mike Biddle (2011)
item.itunes:author: Mike Biddle
item.description: Less than 10% of plastic trash is recycled -- compared to almost 90% of metals -- because of the massively complicated problem of finding and sorting the different kinds. Frustrated by this waste, Mike Biddle has developed a cheap and incredibly energy efficient plant that can, and does, recycle any kind of plastic.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mike Biddle: We can recycle plastic
item.itunes:summary: Less than 10% of plastic trash is recycled -- compared to almost 90% of metals -- because of the massively complicated problem of finding and sorting the different kinds. Frustrated by this waste, Mike Biddle has developed a cheap and incredibly energy efficient plant that can, and does, recycle any kind of plastic.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Graham Hill: Less stuff, more happiness - Graham Hill (2011)
item.itunes:author: Graham Hill
item.description: Writer and designer Graham Hill asks: Can having less stuff, in less room, lead to more happiness? He makes the case for taking up less space, and lays out three rules for editing your life.
item.itunes:subtitle: Graham Hill: Less stuff, more happiness
item.itunes:summary: Writer and designer Graham Hill asks: Can having less stuff, in less room, lead to more happiness? He makes the case for taking up less space, and lays out three rules for editing your life.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Christoph Adami: Finding life we can't imagine - Christoph Adami (2011)
item.itunes:author: Christoph Adami
item.description: How do we search for alien life if it's nothing like the life that we know? At TEDxUIUC Christoph Adami shows how he uses his research into artificial life -- self-replicating computer programs -- to find a signature, a 'biomarker,' that is free of our preconceptions of what life is.
item.itunes:subtitle: Christoph Adami: Finding life we can't imagine
item.itunes:summary: How do we search for alien life if it's nothing like the life that we know? At TEDxUIUC Christoph Adami shows how he uses his research into artificial life -- self-replicating computer programs -- to find a signature, a 'biomarker,' that is free of our preconceptions of what life is.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Yang Lan: The generation that's remaking China - Yang Lan (2011)
item.itunes:author: Yang Lan
item.description: Yang Lan, a journalist and entrepreneur who's been called "the Oprah of China," offers insight into the next generation of young Chinese citizens -- urban, connected (via microblogs) and alert to injustice.
item.itunes:subtitle: Yang Lan: The generation that's remaking China
item.itunes:summary: Yang Lan, a journalist and entrepreneur who's been called "the Oprah of China," offers insight into the next generation of young Chinese citizens -- urban, connected (via microblogs) and alert to injustice.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Danielle de Niese: A flirtatious aria - Danielle de Niese (2011)
item.itunes:author: Danielle de Niese
item.description: Can opera be ever-so-slightly sexy? The glorious soprano Danielle de Niese shows how, singing the flirty "Meine Lippen, sie küssen so heiss." Which, translated, means, as you might guess: "I kiss so hot." From Giuditta by Frans Lehár; accompanist: Ingrid Surgenor.
item.itunes:subtitle: Danielle de Niese: A flirtatious aria
item.itunes:summary: Can opera be ever-so-slightly sexy? The glorious soprano Danielle de Niese shows how, singing the flirty "Meine Lippen, sie küssen so heiss." Which, translated, means, as you might guess: "I kiss so hot." From Giuditta by Frans Lehár; accompanist: Ingrid Surgenor.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Ben Goldacre: Battling bad science - Ben Goldacre (2011)
item.itunes:author: Ben Goldacre
item.description: Every day there are news reports of new health advice, but how can you know if they're right? Doctor and epidemiologist Ben Goldacre shows us, at high speed, the ways evidence can be distorted, from the blindingly obvious nutrition claims to the very subtle tricks of the pharmaceutical industry.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ben Goldacre: Battling bad science
item.itunes:summary: Every day there are news reports of new health advice, but how can you know if they're right? Doctor and epidemiologist Ben Goldacre shows us, at high speed, the ways evidence can be distorted, from the blindingly obvious nutrition claims to the very subtle tricks of the pharmaceutical industry.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Jarreth Merz: Filming democracy in Ghana - Jarreth Merz (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jarreth Merz
item.description: Jarreth Merz, a Swiss-Ghanaian filmmaker, came to Ghana in 2008 to film the national elections. What he saw there taught him new lessons about democracy -- and about himself.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jarreth Merz: Filming democracy in Ghana
item.itunes:summary: Jarreth Merz, a Swiss-Ghanaian filmmaker, came to Ghana in 2008 to film the national elections. What he saw there taught him new lessons about democracy -- and about himself.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Geoff Mulgan: A short intro to the Studio School - Geoff Mulgan (2011)
item.itunes:author: Geoff Mulgan
item.description: Some kids learn by listening; others learn by doing. Geoff Mulgan gives a short introduction to the Studio School, a new kind of school in the UK where small teams of kids learn by working on projects that are, as Mulgan puts it, "for real."
item.itunes:subtitle: Geoff Mulgan: A short intro to the Studio School
item.itunes:summary: Some kids learn by listening; others learn by doing. Geoff Mulgan gives a short introduction to the Studio School, a new kind of school in the UK where small teams of kids learn by working on projects that are, as Mulgan puts it, "for real."
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Abraham Verghese: A doctor's touch - Abraham Verghese (2011)
item.itunes:author: Abraham Verghese
item.description: Modern medicine is in danger of losing a powerful, old-fashioned tool: human touch. Physician and writer Abraham Verghese describes our strange new world where patients are merely data points, and calls for a return to the traditional one-on-one physical exam.
item.itunes:subtitle: Abraham Verghese: A doctor's touch
item.itunes:summary: Modern medicine is in danger of losing a powerful, old-fashioned tool: human touch. Physician and writer Abraham Verghese describes our strange new world where patients are merely data points, and calls for a return to the traditional one-on-one physical exam.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Sunni Brown: Doodlers, unite! - Sunni Brown (2011)
item.itunes:author: Sunni Brown
item.description: Studies show that sketching and doodling improve our comprehension -- and our creative thinking. So why do we still feel embarrassed when we're caught doodling in a meeting? Sunni Brown says: Doodlers, unite! She makes the case for unlocking your brain via pad and pen.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunni Brown: Doodlers, unite!
item.itunes:summary: Studies show that sketching and doodling improve our comprehension -- and our creative thinking. So why do we still feel embarrassed when we're caught doodling in a meeting? Sunni Brown says: Doodlers, unite! She makes the case for unlocking your brain via pad and pen.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

channel.media:description: TED is a nonprofit devoted to Ideas Worth Spreading. On this feed, you'll find TEDTalks video to inspire, intrigue and stir the imagination from some of the world's leading thinkers and doers, speaking from the stage at TED conferences, TEDx events and pa
